articles.title: Restoration of the Archaeological Museum of Durrës in Albania nearing completion, thanks to the EU4Culture programme
articles.summary: The Archaeological Museum of Durrës is one of the sites damaged by the 2019 earthquake, which has been under restoration since 2022 within the framework of the EU4Culture project financed by the EU.
articles.content:
The Archaeological Museum of Durrës is one of the sites damaged by the 2019 earthquake, which has been under restoration since 2022 within the framework of the EU4Culture project financed by the EU.

The National Archaeological Museum in Durrës, a coastal city in Albania, is on the verge of completing restoration works thanks to the EU4Culture program funded by the European Union.

Soon, over 2,400 objects will be exhibited in completely new pavilions, with contemporary lighting and conditions.

As part of this investment, the museum courtyard has also been reconceived to be transformed into an attractive space for visitors, cultural activities, and education.

Likewise, thanks to the works and reconceptualization, the museum will become a point of reference for researchers and history enthusiasts, as well as one of the main cultural attractions of Durrës.

The Archaeological Museum of Durrës is one of the buildings damaged by the 2019 earthquake, which has been under restoration since 2022 within the framework of the EU4Culture project funded by the EU.

It is the largest archaeological museum in Albania with a wide collection consisting of more than 3000 artifacts discovered in the ancient area of Dyrrah, which shows the development of the city of Durrës during late antiquity and the medieval period.

After the renovation, the museum will have a modern appearance and will be transformed into a modern educational center that will allow visitors to immerse themselves in and experience ancient history through classical storytelling and high technology, as well as virtual reality and multimedia tools.

Visitors will be able to navigate the ancient history of Durrës by exploring redrawn streets, marvel at the new treasures discovered during recent underwater archaeological missions, and gather together for cultural events and performances.

The EU4Culture project is funded by the European Union (EU) and implemented by the United Nations Office for Project Services (UNOPS) in close partnership with the Ministry of Culture of Albania.

It focuses on the renovation and revitalization of key cultural heritage sites damaged by the earthquake and represents one of the largest cultural heritage programs funded by the European Union with a total budget of 40 million euros.

In parallel, the project aims to increase Albania’s tourism potential, thus contributing directly to local and regional socio-economic recovery. For this purpose, special focus is dedicated to innovative technologies, including digital storytelling and the creation of multimedia products designed to be accessible to everyone. At the same time, the project is supporting local entrepreneurship, craftsmanship, and cultural initiatives that develop around the selected areas through the distribution of grants, providing a direct boost to the local economy. (30 December)
articles.reasoning: The article describes the near completion of restoration of a major cultural heritage site damaged by an earthquake, funded by a significant EU program. This restoration has broad cultural and educational benefits, enhances tourism potential, supports local economy and entrepreneurship, and incorporates innovative technologies for accessibility. The story has clear positive real-world impact, significant scope for the public and cultural community, and sufficient detail about the project and its benefits.

articles.title: EU provides financial support for small and medium-sized enterprises in North Macedonia
articles.summary: The lending is intended for the business sector that does not have sufficient access to financing, primarily businesses run by women and young entrepreneurs, rural small and medium-sized enterprises, as well as projects for strengthening inclusive economic development.
articles.content:
The lending is intended for the business sector that does not have sufficient access to financing, primarily businesses run by women and young entrepreneurs, rural small and medium-sized enterprises, as well as projects for strengthening inclusive economic development.

Skopje – The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) has signed an agreement with ProCredit Bank for a guarantee of up to 25 million euros, to cover 50 percent of the risk for new loans to finance small and medium-sized enterprises in North Macedonia in a total amount of up to 50 million euros.

The guarantee is supported by technical assistance from the European Fund for Sustainable Development Plus and in this way the EBRD and the EU, by sharing part of the risk, help ProCredit to strengthen its resilience and increase lending.

The lending is intended for the business sector that does not have sufficient access to financing, primarily businesses run by women and young entrepreneurs, rural small and medium-sized enterprises, as well as projects to strengthen inclusive economic development.

According to the EBRD representative for North Macedonia, Fatih Turkmenoglu, this partnership supported by the European Union marks an important step towards expanding access to finance for less supported businesses in the country.

– By sharing the risk and introducing innovative financial tools with specifically approved technical assistance, we help small and medium-sized enterprises to invest with confidence in their own growth and resilience. This represents inclusive and sustainable financing by the EBRD, which is committed to advancing the entire Western Balkans, said Turkmenoglu.

The EBRD is the leading institutional investor in North Macedonia, with more than 3 billion euros invested in support of sustainable development, infrastructure, private sector growth and the country’s regional integration. (30 December 2025)
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant financial support initiative by the EU and EBRD to improve access to financing for small and medium-sized enterprises in North Macedonia, especially targeting women, young entrepreneurs, and rural businesses. This has a broad positive impact on inclusive economic development and sustainable growth in the region, with clear details on the funding and its intended beneficiaries.
articles.personality_title: EU and EBRD boost loans for small businesses in North Macedonia
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Many small and medium-sized businesses in North Macedonia struggle to get loans, especially those run by women, young people, or located in rural areas. This limits their ability to grow and contribute to the economy.

**What happened** – The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) teamed up with ProCredit Bank to offer loans worth up to 50 million euros to these businesses. The EBRD will guarantee half of this amount, meaning it will cover 25 million euros of the risk if loans are not paid back. This agreement was signed in Skopje and is supported by the European Union through technical help.

**Impact** – This deal makes it easier and safer for banks to lend money to small businesses that usually find it hard to get loans. By focusing on women-led, young entrepreneurs, and rural companies, the program supports groups that often face extra challenges. This will help more businesses invest, grow, and create jobs, making the local economy stronger and more inclusive.

**What's next step** – ProCredit Bank will start giving out the new loans using this guarantee. The EBRD and EU will continue to support the process with advice and tools to make sure the loans help businesses succeed and contribute to sustainable economic development.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The EU and EBRD have created a new fund to help small businesses in North Macedonia, especially those led by women and young people, get the loans they need to grow and create jobs.

articles.title: Romania receives over 586 million euros from the European Commission for transport investments
articles.summary: The European Commission has transferred to Romania over 586 million euros from European funds, money intended for major investments in transport infrastructure.
articles.content:
The European Commission has transferred to Romania over 586 million euros from European funds, money intended for major investments in transport infrastructure.

Bucharest – The European Commission has transferred to Romania over 586 million euros from the Cohesion Fund and the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) under the 2021-2027 Transport Programme, Minister of Finance Alexandru Nazare announced on his Facebook page on Tuesday.

According to the minister’s post, the payment is linked to major infrastructure investments, including the Ploieşti-Buzău-Focşani motorway, which were initially included in the National Recovery and Resilience Plan (PNRR). However, between September and December this year, in consultation with the European Commission, the government transferred these projects to the 2021-2027 Transport Programme, allowing for a more efficient use of EU funds.

Nazare stressed that the transferred funds are EU grants, not Romanian taxpayers’ money, and will be directed straight into the Romanian economy, mainly to finance the development of transport infrastructure, regional investments and public services.

The minister also announced that on Sunday the Ministry of Finance transferred a total of 714 million lei to several local authorities to cover their share of local investments financed from non-reimbursable grants related to the PNRR. (30.12.2025)
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant transfer of EU funds to Romania for major transport infrastructure investments, which will have a broad positive impact on the economy and public services. The funding is substantial and tied to large-scale projects, indicating meaningful progress in regional development and infrastructure improvement. The story has clear substance and context, focusing on a single topic with tangible benefits for the general public.
articles.personality_title: Romania receives over 586 million euros from the European Commission for transport investments
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The European Union provides money to member countries to help improve important projects like roads and public services. Romania is one of these countries, working to upgrade its transport system.

**What happened** – The European Commission sent more than 586 million euros to Romania. This money comes from two EU funds: the Cohesion Fund and the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF). The funds are part of a program running from 2021 to 2027 focused on transport improvements. The money will support big projects, including building a new motorway connecting the cities of Ploieşti, Buzău, and Focşani. These projects were originally planned under another program called the National Recovery and Resilience Plan but were moved to the current transport program to use the money more efficiently.

**Impact** – This large amount of money will help build better roads and improve transport in Romania. It is not money from Romanian taxpayers but grants from the EU, which means it does not have to be paid back. The investments will boost the economy by creating jobs and making travel easier and safer for people and goods. It will also support regional growth and improve public services.

**What’s next step** – Romania will use this funding to carry out the planned transport projects over the next few years. Local authorities have also received money to help with investments funded by the EU’s recovery plan. These projects are expected to continue improving the country’s infrastructure and help Romania meet its development goals.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The European Commission’s transfer of over 586 million euros to Romania will support major transport projects that strengthen the country’s economy and infrastructure without using local taxpayers’ money.

articles.personality_title_es: Rumanía recibe más de 586 millones de euros de la Comisión Europea para inversiones en transporte

Este dinero proviene de dos fondos de la UE: el Fondo de Cohesión y el Fondo Europeo de Desarrollo Regional (FEDER). Los fondos forman parte de un programa de transporte que va de 2021 a 2027. El dinero se usará para grandes proyectos, incluyendo la construcción de una nueva autopista que conectará las ciudades de Ploieşti, Buzău y Focşani. Estos proyectos estaban planeados originalmente bajo otro programa llamado Plan Nacional de Recuperación y Resiliencia, pero se trasladaron al programa actual para usar mejor los fondos.

Las inversiones impulsarán la economía creando empleos y facilitando los viajes de personas y mercancías. También apoyarán el crecimiento regional y mejorarán los servicios públicos.

**Próximo paso** – Rumanía usará estos fondos para realizar los proyectos de transporte planeados en los próximos años. Las autoridades locales también recibieron dinero para ayudar con inversiones financiadas por el plan de recuperación de la UE. Se espera que estos proyectos sigan mejorando la infraestructura del país y ayuden a Rumanía a alcanzar sus metas de desarrollo.

**Resumen en una frase** – La transferencia de más de 586 millones de euros por parte de la Comisión Europea apoyará proyectos importantes de transporte que fortalecerán la economía y la infraestructura de Rumanía sin usar dinero de los contribuyentes locales.
